Introduction

Sj√∂gren disease (formerly Sj√∂gren syndrome) is a chronic autoimmune disorder that is most common in middle-aged and older women.  It is characterized by inflammation and dysfunction of the salivary and lacrimal glands, leading to dry mouth (xerostomia) and dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca), and can have multisystem manifestations beyond glandular dysfunction.  Sj√∂gren disease can occur as a primary condition or in association with other autoimmune diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis or systemic lupus erythematosus.

Pathophysiology



Sj√∂gren disease results from immune-mediated destruction of the exocrine glands, primarily the lacrimal and salivary glands.  Inflammation in Sj√∂gren disease involves both innate and acquired immune responses.  A genetic predisposition is likely, and it is associated with certain histocompatibility subtypes (eg, human leukocyte antigen DR3 [HLA-DR3], HLA-B8).  The inflammatory cascade is postulated to be triggered by a variety of environmental antigens, especially viruses (eg, Epstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus, hepatitis viruses).



CD4+ T cells infiltrate glandular tissue, leading to inflammation, atrophy, and fibrosis.  Autoantibodies, including anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB, contribute to pathogenesis by targeting ribonucleoproteins involved in RNA processing, and are highly useful in making the diagnosis.  The associated B-cell hyperactivity increases the risk for lymphoproliferative disorders, particularly non-Hodgkin lymphoma.



The pathogenesis of extraglandular manifestations is variable and multifactorial.  Contributing factors can include autoantibody attack, immune complex deposition, cell-mediated immunity, and upregulated inflammatory cytokine production (eg, interferon-gamma, tumor necrosis factor-alpha).

Risk factors



  • Female sex:  ‚â•9:1 female/male ratio.  Estrogen and testosterone may be protective factors (incidence is highest in postmenopausal women).
  • Age:  Peak incidence in the fourth to sixth decades.
  • Personal or family history of autoimmune disease.

Pathology



Histologic examination of affected salivary glands shows periductal and perivascular lymphocytic infiltration, often with germinal centers (

image 1
).  In advanced disease, findings include acinar atrophy and fibrosis; glandular architecture is disrupted, and epimyoepithelial islands may be present.  Focal lymphocytic sialadenitis on labial salivary gland biopsy is a characteristic finding.

Clinical presentation



The hallmark manifestations of Sj√∂gren disease include dry eyes and dry mouth.  Ocular symptoms include a gritty sensation, burning, and blurred vision, whereas oral symptoms include enlarged salivary glands, difficulty swallowing dry foods, accelerated dental caries, and oral candidiasis.



Extraglandular disease can involve almost any organ system.  Major manifestations include the following:



  • Musculoskeletal:  Arthralgia, nonerosive arthritis, inflammatory myopathy.
  • Cutaneous:  Xerosis, annular erythema, vasculitis.
  • Respiratory:  Interstitial lung disease, bronchiectasis, cystic lung disease, upper airway disease (eg, nonallergic rhinosinusitis).
  • Gastrointestinal:  Dysphagia, atrophic gastritis, hepatobiliary disease.
  • Renal:  Tubulointerstitial nephritis, chronic kidney disease, distal (type 1) renal tubular acidosis.
  • Genitourinary:  Dysuria/interstitial cystitis, dyspareunia, vaginal dryness.
  • Neuropsychiatric:  Peripheral neuropathy, dysautonomia, affective symptoms, sleep disorders.
  • Vascular:  Raynaud phenomenon.
  • Hematologic:  Cytopenias, polyclonal and monoclonal gammopathies.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of Sj√∂gren disease is based on a combination of clinical findings, serologic markers (see later section), and histopathology.



Objective evidence of decreased tear or saliva production is helpful because subjective sensations of dry eye or dry mouth are common and highly nonspecific.  For example, in the Schirmer test, a standardized strip of filter paper is placed at the eyelid margin and allowed to wick the tears for 5 minutes; the extent of wetting is measured (<5 mm is typical in patients with keratoconjunctivitis sicca).  Unstimulated salivary flow rate can also be measured.  In addition, assessment of corneal damage can be performed with staining of the ocular surface with rose bengal stain, fluorescein, or lissamine green (

image 2
).



Standardized diagnostic criteria, such as the American College of Rheumatology/European League Against Rheumatism (ACR/EULAR) scoring system, can be used to diagnose Sj√∂gren disease for classification purposes and research.  These systems use weighted scoring of secretory measurements, serologic results, and histopathology to establish the diagnosis.  However, as with many rheumatologic conditions, nonclassic cases that do not meet all the criteria are common in clinical practice.

Laboratory/imaging evaluation



  • Nonspecific laboratory findings:  Anemia, leukopenia, hypergammaglobulinemia, elevated liver transaminase levels, elevated inflammatory markers (eg, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein).
  • Serologic tests:
    • Antinuclear antibody:  Positive in 60%-80% of patients but nonspecific.
    • Anti-Ro/SSA, anti-La/SSB:  Moderately specific and associated with more severe disease.
    • Rheumatoid factor:  Does not establish concurrent rheumatoid arthritis; anti‚Äìcyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies may also be present and are more specific for rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Histologic testing:  If noninvasive tests do not confirm the diagnosis, biopsy of the labial salivary glands can be performed easily and is diagnostic.  Parotid and submandibular gland biopsy is more involved and typically performed if malignancy (eg, lymphoma, salivary adenocarcinoma) is suspected.
  • Imaging:
    • Salivary gland ultrasonography:  Has good specificity when classic findings are present and can guide needle biopsy if secondary malignancy is suspected.  Characteristic findings include multifocal hypoechoic areas, hyperechoic bands, and calcifications.
    • Salivary gland MRI:  Reveals nodular inhomogeneity with a honeycomb pattern, fibrosis, and dilation of the salivary ducts.

Differential diagnosis



  • Medication-induced (eg, anticholinergics, antihistamines) secretory impairment

    • Similarities:  Dry mouth and dry eyes.
    • Differences:  Symptom improvement with discontinuation of offending drug; no autoantibodies.
  • Sarcoidosis (frequently coexists with Sj√∂gren disease)
    • Similarities:  Dry mouth and eyes, multisystem manifestations (eg, fatigue, arthralgia).
    • Differences:  Hypercalcemia, hilar adenitis, uveitis, noncaseating granulomas on biopsy.
  • IgG4-related disease
    • Similarities:  Salivary and lacrimal gland dysfunction, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates on biopsy.
    • Differences:  IgG4-positive plasma cells, elevated serum IgG4, extensive fibrosis on biopsy.
  • Miscellaneous causes of exocrine dysfunction
    • Similarities:  Age-related dry eye/dry mouth (
      üìä View Table: table 1
      ), radiation-induced salivary injury, graft versus host disease, decreased blinking (eg, Parkinson disease), subjective dry eye without lacrimal dysfunction (eg, dry/high-wind climate, allergic conjunctivitis).
    • Differences:  Inflammatory markers and serologies are normal; objective tests of lacrimal secretions (eg, Schirmer test) may be normal or paradoxically increased.

Management



  • Symptomatic treatment:  Artificial tears, saliva substitutes, secretagogues (eg, sugar-free sour lozenges), punctal plugs for severe dry eye, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for mild musculoskeletal symptoms.
  • Dental and ophthalmologic care:  Preventive dental hygiene and regular eye examinations to monitor for complications.
  • Systemic therapy:  Pilocarpine or cevimeline (muscarinic agonists) for xerostomia.
  • Immunosuppressive therapy:  Corticosteroids, immunosuppressants (eg, methotrexate, hydroxychloroquine, rituximab) for severe extraglandular involvement.

Complications

Local glandular sequelae



  • Dental caries and oral candidiasis:  Salivary hypofunction impairs antimicrobial defense and pH buffering.
  • Corneal ulceration:  Tear film instability and epithelial damage lead to corneal injury.
  • Bacterial sialadenitis:  Stasis of protein-rich saliva promotes ascending ductal infection.

Systemic autoimmune involvement



  • Neurologic:  Immune-mediated injury to peripheral nerves (axonal or demyelinating); CNS demyelination may mimic multiple sclerosis.
  • Pulmonary:  Lymphocytic infiltration that causes interstitial lung disease; chronic inflammation may lead to pulmonary hypertension.
  • Renal:  CD4+ T cell‚Äìmediated tubulointerstitial nephritis; impaired acid secretion causes distal (type 1) renal tubular acidosis.
  • Vascular:  Endothelial dysfunction and vasospasm, which result in Raynaud phenomenon.

Malignancy risk



  • Non-Hodgkin lymphoma:  B-cell hyperactivity, especially in ectopic germinal centers, predisposes to mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma.

Pregnancy-related risks



  • Fetal heart block:  Transplacental anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB antibodies injure fetal cardiac conduction tissue.

Prognosis



Sj√∂gren disease is a chronic disease with variable progression.  Most patients experience stable or slowly progressive sicca symptoms, but systemic manifestations can also significantly impact the quality of life.  The risk for lymphoma is a major concern, particularly in patients with persistent parotid swelling, lymphadenopathy, or cryoglobulinemia.  Lifelong monitoring is recommended to assess for disease progression and complications.

Summary



Sj√∂gren disease is a chronic autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the exocrine glands, causing dry mouth and eyes.  It involves immune-mediated destruction of the exocrine glands and can occur alone or with other autoimmune disorders.  Risk factors include female sex, age, and autoimmune history.  Diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical findings, serologic markers (anti-Ro/SSA, anti-La/SSB), and histopathology.  Management includes symptomatic treatment, systemic therapy, and immunosuppression for severe cases.  Complications include dental caries, lymphoma, and neuropathy.  Prognosis is variable, requiring lifelong monitoring.
